title: The rise of the Ottoman Empire - Mostafa Minawi

multiple-choice.question: Who established a small beylik, or principality, in what is now Turkey in the late 13th century?
What was the primary reason for the Ottoman Empire's rapid rise to power?

options.label: A
options.text: Its strategic location between the Byzantine Empire and the Sultanate of the Seljuk of Rum

options.label: B
options.text: Its strong ethnic and religious affinity with neighboring principalities

options.label: C
options.text: Its sophisticated military organization and tax collection system

options.label: D
options.text: A combination of strategic political alliances, military conflicts, and attracting mercenaries

Who conquered Constantinople in 1453 and made it the Ottoman capital?
What was the name of the famous architect who designed many mosques and buildings in Istanbul?
What was the name of the ceramics made using techniques from China's Ming dynasty, reimagined with Ottoman motifs?
At its peak, the Ottoman Empire stretched from which regions?

options.label: A
options.text: Hungary to the Persian Gulf, from the Horn of Africa to the Crimean Peninsula

options.label: B
options.text: Turkey to the Middle East, from North Africa to Eastern Europe

options.label: C
options.text: Europe to Asia, from the Mediterranean to the Black Sea

options.label: D
options.text: The Balkans to Anatolia, from the Aegean to the Mediterranean

multiple-choice.question: How long did the Ottoman Empire last?

title: Savitri and Satyavan: The legend of the princess who outwitted Death - Iseult Gillespie

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: What did Princess Savitri swear to do when she learned of Satyavan's fate?

multiple-choice.question: What was Princess Savitri's clever question that made Yamraj relent?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: What was the purpose of life and death?

options.label: A

options.label: B

title: Do personality tests work? - Merve Emre

multiple-choice.question: Who developed the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI) in 1942?

options.label: A
options.text: Katherine Cook Briggs and Isabel Briggs Myers

multiple-choice.question: What is a major criticism of personality tests like the MBTI and the Big Five?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too long and tedious to complete.

options.label: B
options.text: They are too expensive for individuals to use.

options.label: C
options.text: They do not reveal truths about personality and are often inconsistent.

options.label: D
options.text: They are only used by companies and not by individuals.

multiple-choice.question: Why are self-reported personality tests problematic?

options.label: A
options.text: Because people often lie on the tests.

options.label: B
options.text: Because people may not understand the questions.

options.label: C
options.text: Because objective self-evaluation is tricky, and people may subconsciously aim to please.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the tests are too short.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a forced-choice question on the MBTI?

options.label: B
options.text: What do you value more, justice or fairness?

multiple-choice.question: According to research, what happens when people take the Myers-Briggs a second time after a short period?

options.label: A
options.text: They always get the same result.

options.label: B
options.text: They often get a similar result.

options.label: C
options.text: Nearly half of people get assigned a different type.

multiple-choice.question: How have the definitions of personality traits like introversion and extroversion changed over time?

options.label: C
options.text: They have changed significantly, with introversion originally meaning sticking to principles and later meaning shyness or preferring alone time.

multiple-choice.question: What does research suggest about personality?

options.label: B
options.text: It shifts during key periods, such as school years or when starting work.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only shaped by upbringing.

multiple-choice.question: Why is the use of personality tests in schools and companies problematic?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it helps people discover their strengths and weaknesses.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it advises students what to study and what jobs to pursue, but the results don't predict performance.

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential consequence of using personality tests to decide who to hire or what positions to offer?

options.label: A
options.text: It can lead to more diversity in the workplace.

options.label: B
options.text: It can deprive people of opportunities they'd excel at or discourage them from considering certain paths.

multiple-choice.question: How should personality test results be taken?

options.label: C
options.text: As a definitive guide for life decisions.

options.label: D
options.text: As a way to diagnose mental health issues.

title: Climate change will displace millions. Here's how we prepare - Colette Pichon Battle

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's reaction when they first saw the Louisiana flood maps?

options.label: A
options.text: They were indifferent to the information presented.

options.label: B
options.text: They were relieved that their community was not affected.

options.label: C
options.text: Their life changed for the second time in two years as they realized the impact on their community.

options.label: D
options.text: They were already aware of the land loss and its consequences.

multiple-choice.question: What is predicted to happen to over 180 million people by the end of the next century due to climate change?

options.label: A
options.text: They will be forced to adapt to new technologies.

options.label: B
options.text: They will be displaced from their homes.

options.label: C
options.text: They will experience severe economic losses.

options.label: D
options.text: They will be unaffected by climate change.

multiple-choice.question: What is "climate gentrification," and where is it happening?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the process of people moving to higher ground, happening in places like Miami.

options.label: B
options.text: It is the process of people being forced to relocate due to rising housing costs, happening in places like Miami.

options.label: C
options.text: It is the process of people adapting to new climate-resilient technologies, happening globally.

options.label: D
options.text: It is the process of people being displaced due to extreme weather events, happening in coastal areas.

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker suggest is the root cause of the climate crisis?

options.label: A
options.text: Climate change is the problem itself.

options.label: B
options.text: The root cause is the increasing global population.

options.label: C
options.text: The root cause is an economic system built for a few to extract value from the planet and its people.

options.label: D
options.text: The root cause is the lack of technological advancements.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is necessary for human survival in the face of climate change?

options.label: A
options.text: Continuing our current economic and social systems.

options.label: C
options.text: Restructuring our social and economic systems to develop collective resilience.

options.label: D
options.text: Focusing on individual actions to reduce carbon emissions.

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker mean by "reindigenizing ourselves"?

options.label: A
options.text: It means adopting indigenous cultures and practices.

options.label: B
options.text: It means learning to follow and respect the leadership and traditional knowledge of local places.

options.label: C
options.text: It means dismissing the importance of indigenous knowledge.

options.label: D
options.text: It means exploiting indigenous resources for economic gain.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's vision for a new society in the face of climate change?

options.label: A
options.text: A society that prioritizes individualism and economic growth.

options.label: B
options.text: A society that values collective resilience, ecological equity, and human rights.

options.label: C
options.text: A society that relies solely on technological advancements.

options.label: D
options.text: A society that ignores the impacts of climate change.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is required for us to survive the climate crisis?

options.label: A
options.text: Recognizing a power greater than ourselves and a life longer than the ones we will live.

options.label: B
options.text: Focusing solely on reducing carbon emissions.

options.label: C
options.text: Continuing our current economic and social systems.

options.label: D
options.text: Ignoring the impacts of climate change.

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker mean by "shared liberation"?

options.label: A
options.text: It means individual freedom from climate-related hardships.

options.label: B
options.text: It means collective freedom and equality for all people.

options.label: C
options.text: It means economic growth and prosperity for a select few.

options.label: D
options.text: It means ignoring the impacts of climate change.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message to the audience?

options.label: A
options.text: We are powerless against climate change.

options.label: B
options.text: We must continue our current economic and social systems.

options.label: C
options.text: We can make a difference by working together to create a just and fair society.

options.label: D
options.text: We should focus solely on reducing carbon emissions.

options.label: C

title: 10 ways to have a better conversation - Celeste Headlee

multiple-choice.question: What is the main topic of the talk?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of technology in our daily lives.

options.label: B
options.text: The art of having a conversation and truly listening to others.

options.label: C
options.text: The benefits of social media in connecting people.

options.label: D
options.text: The impact of climate change on our society.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the current state of our society in terms of conversations and relationships?

options.label: A
options.text: We are more connected and united than ever before.

options.label: B
options.text: We are more polarized and divided than ever before.

options.label: C
options.text: We are experiencing a mix of both unity and division.

options.label: D
options.text: We are not affected by technology in our relationships.

multiple-choice.question: What is the first rule of having a good conversation, according to the speaker?

options.label: D
options.text: Repeat back what you just heard.

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker mean by "conversational competence"?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability to speak multiple languages.

options.label: B
options.text: The ability to communicate effectively and respectfully with others.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the most important skill to develop in having good conversations?
What does the speaker mean by "staying out of the weeds" in a conversation?

options.label: B
options.text: Focusing on the details and facts of a topic.

options.label: C
options.text: Avoiding getting bogged down in unnecessary details.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, why do people often struggle to listen to others?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are not interested in the topic.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they would rather talk and be the center of attention.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are distracted and their minds wander.

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker quote Stephen Covey as saying about listening?

options.label: A
options.text: "Most of us don't listen with the intent to understand. We listen with the intent to reply."

options.label: B
options.text: "Most of us listen with the intent to understand. We don't listen with the intent to reply."

multiple-choice.question: What is the final rule of having a good conversation, according to the speaker?

options.label: D
options.text: Repeat back what you just heard.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the key to being a good conversationalist?

options.label: A
options.text: Being an expert in a particular topic.

options.label: B
options.text: Being able to talk at length about a topic.

options.label: C
options.text: Being interested in other people and truly listening to them.

options.label: D
options.text: Being able to dominate a conversation.

title: Why is pneumonia so dangerous? - Eve Gaus and Vanessa Ruiz

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the alveoli in the lungs?

options.label: A
options.text: To filter out pathogens from the air we breathe

options.label: B
options.text: To facilitate the exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide between the air and bloodstream

options.label: C
options.text: To produce mucus to trap invaders

multiple-choice.question: What is pneumonia, and how does it affect the lungs?

options.label: A
options.text: Pneumonia is a type of cancer that affects the lungs

options.label: B
options.text: Pneumonia is an infection of the alveoli that causes them to fill with fluid

options.label: C
options.text: Pneumonia is a type of asthma that affects the lungs

options.label: D
options.text: Pneumonia is a type of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)

multiple-choice.question: What is the mucociliary escalator, and how does it help defend against pathogens?

options.label: A
options.text: The mucociliary escalator is a type of white blood cell that defends against pathogens

options.label: B
options.text: The mucociliary escalator is a mechanism that traps invaders and carries them toward the mouth to be coughed out

options.label: C
options.text: The mucociliary escalator is a type of antibiotic that helps fight infections

options.label: D
options.text: The mucociliary escalator is a type of vaccine that protects against pneumonia

multiple-choice.question: What happens when pathogens enter the lungs and meet the alveoli?

options.label: A
options.text: The alveoli produce more mucus to trap the pathogens

options.label: B
options.text: The macrophages work to destroy the pathogens, and the immune system releases additional white blood cells to help

options.label: C
options.text: The pathogens are immediately cleared out of the lungs

options.label: D
options.text: The alveoli become damaged and unable to function properly

multiple-choice.question: What is the most common symptom of pneumonia?
How is pneumonia typically treated?

options.label: A
options.text: With antibiotics, which may include either antibacterial or antiviral treatments

options.label: B
options.text: With surgery to remove the infected lung tissue

options.label: C
options.text: With oxygen therapy to help increase oxygen levels in the blood

options.label: D
options.text: With rest and hydration to help the body recover on its own

multiple-choice.question: Who is most susceptible to severe pneumonia?

options.label: C
options.text: People with genetic and autoimmune disorders

multiple-choice.question: What can happen if the body enters a sustained fight against the infection?

options.label: A
options.text: The body will eventually clear out the infection on its own

options.label: B
options.text: The body may enter a state of shock and experience organ failure

options.label: C
options.text: The body will become immune to future infections

options.label: D
options.text: The body will experience a prolonged recovery period

multiple-choice.question: How can pneumonia be prevented?

options.label: A
options.text: By getting enough sleep and exercise

options.label: C
options.text: By getting vaccinated against common pneumonia-causing pathogens

multiple-choice.question: Why are many deaths from pneumonia due to lack of access to healthcare?

options.label: A
options.text: Because pneumonia is a highly contagious disease

options.label: B
options.text: Because pneumonia is a disease that can be easily treated with antibiotics

options.label: C
options.text: Because many people do not have access to medical care, making it difficult to receive proper treatment

options.label: D
options.text: Because pneumonia is a disease that can be prevented with vaccination

options.label: A
options.text: Squaring a Fibonacci number gives you a value that's one more or one less than the product of the Fibonacci numbers on either side of it.

options.text: Squaring a Fibonacci number gives you a value that's equal to the product of the Fibonacci numbers on either side of it.

options.label: C
options.text: Squaring a Fibonacci number gives you a value that's two more or two less than the product of the Fibonacci numbers on either side of it.

title: How fast is the speed of thought? - Seena Mathew

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary factor that determines how quickly you think?

options.label: B
options.text: The distance the signal has to travel

options.label: C
options.text: The time it takes to generate an initial action potential, propagate it down the length of the axon, and transport it through the synapse

options.label: D
options.text: The strength of the electrical impulses

options.label: B
options.text: To propagate signals down the length of the axon

options.label: C
options.text: To transport signals through the synapse

options.label: D
options.text: To insulate an axon and prevent electrical currents from leaking out

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the speed of thought as you reach old age?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases due to the growth of new neurons

options.label: C
options.text: It decreases due to the degradation of neuronal structures

options.label: A
options.text: Because the arrow is traveling at a faster speed than the thought

options.label: B
options.text: Because the thought has to travel a longer distance than the arrow

options.label: C
options.text: Because the arrow leaves the gate before the thought can start down its path

options.label: D
options.text: Because the thought is slowed down by the complexity of the neural pathways

multiple-choice.question: What is the fastest time in which a startle reaction can occur?
What is the primary factor that determines the duration of a thought?

options.label: A
options.text: The speed of the electrical impulses

options.label: B
options.text: The distance the signal has to travel

options.label: C
options.text: The complexity of the neural pathways

options.label: D
options.text: The strength of the electrical impulses

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the dendrites in the nervous system?

options.label: B
options.text: To propagate signals down the length of the axon

options.label: C
options.text: To receive signals from other neurons

options.label: D
options.text: To transport signals through the synapse

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: Being a spy for the Soviet Union

options.label: D
options.text: Being a member of the US Senate

Who has the burden of proof when making a claim?

options.label: A
options.text: The person listening to the claim

multiple-choice.question: What is the rule of thumb when it comes to claims and evidence?

options.label: A
options.text: The burden of proof lies with the person listening to the claim.

options.label: B
options.text: The burden of proof lies with the person making the claim.

options.label: C
options.text: Claims should be accepted as true without evidence.

options.label: D
options.text: Claims should be rejected as false without evidence.

options.text: He was impeached by the house of representatives.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Thousands of people were incarcerated and hundreds lost their jobs.

options.label: C
options.text: The country became more tolerant of communism.

options.label: D
options.text: The country became more neutral towards communism.

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Are all of your memories real? - Daniel L. Schacter

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the study where participants were told they had gotten lost in a shopping mall as children?

options.label: A
options.text: None of the participants believed they had gotten lost in a mall.

options.label: B
options.text: A quarter of the participants produced false memories of getting lost in a mall.

options.label: C
options.text: All of the participants produced false memories of getting lost in a mall.

options.label: D
options.text: Half of the participants produced false memories of getting lost in a mall.

multiple-choice.question: What is suggestibility in the context of memory?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability to recall memories with perfect accuracy.

options.label: B
options.text: The tendency to incorporate information from outside sources into personal recollections without realizing it.

options.label: C
options.text: The ability to forget memories at will.

options.label: D
options.text: The tendency to only remember positive experiences.

multiple-choice.question: In the study where participants were shown images of a university campus, what was the result?

options.label: A
options.text: None of the participants believed they had visited the campus before.

options.label: B
options.text: A majority of participants said they had probably or definitely visited the campus in the past.

options.label: C
options.text: All of the participants believed they had visited the campus before.

options.label: D
options.text: Half of the participants believed they had visited the campus before.

multiple-choice.question: What is misattribution in the context of memory?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability to recall memories with perfect accuracy.

options.label: B
options.text: The tendency to attribute information from one context to another context.

options.label: C
options.text: The ability to forget memories at will.

options.label: D
options.text: The tendency to only remember positive experiences.

multiple-choice.question: In the study where participants were questioned on their views about the legalization of marijuana, what was the result?

options.label: A
options.text: Participants' current opinions had no effect on their memories of their past views.

options.label: B
options.text: Participants who had changed their views were more likely to recall their past views as being consistent with their current views.

options.label: C
options.text: Participants who had not changed their views were more likely to recall their past views as being inconsistent with their current views.

options.label: D
options.text: Participants' memories of their past views were not influenced by their current opinions.

multiple-choice.question: How can suggestibility impact eyewitness testimony?

options.label: A
options.text: It can lead to more accurate identifications.

options.label: B
options.text: It can lead to incorrect identifications or unreliable confessions.

options.label: C
options.text: It has no impact on eyewitness testimony.

options.label: D
options.text: It can lead to more confident witnesses.

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem with treating memory as fact?

options.label: A
options.text: It can lead to more accurate recollections.

options.label: B
options.text: It can lead to a better understanding of the past.

options.label: C
options.text: It can lead to incorrect assumptions and conclusions.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no impact on our understanding of the past.

multiple-choice.question: How can misattribution impact medical diagnoses?

options.label: A
options.text: It can lead to more accurate diagnoses.

options.label: B
options.text: It can lead to biased conclusions if a physician is aware of a previous diagnosis.

options.label: C
options.text: It has no impact on medical diagnoses.

options.label: D
options.text: It can lead to more confident physicians.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the study where participants were given background information on a historical war?

options.label: A
options.text: The group that knew the outcome of the war rated the winning side as less likely to win.

options.label: B
options.text: The group that knew the outcome of the war rated the winning side as more likely to win.

options.label: C
options.text: The group that did not know the outcome of the war rated the winning side as more likely to win.

options.label: D
options.text: The group that did not know the outcome of the war rated the winning side as less likely to win.

multiple-choice.question: What is the fundamental truth about the nature of our recollections?

options.label: A
options.text: Our memories are ironclad representations of reality.

title: Why people fall for misinformation - Joseph Isaac

multiple-choice.question: Who published a paper in 1901 that led to the development of the taste map?
According to the taste map, which taste is detected at the tip of the tongue?
What is the main problem with the taste map?

options.label: B
options.text: It's not an accurate representation of David Hänig's original discovery

options.label: C
options.text: It only includes four basic tastes

options.label: D
options.text: It's not widely accepted by scientists

multiple-choice.question: What type of information is the tongue map an example of?
Why was David Hänig's dissertation difficult for some people to understand?

options.label: A
options.text: It was written in a complex academic style

options.label: C
options.text: It was too long to read

multiple-choice.question: What contributed to the spread of the tongue map misconception?

options.label: C
options.text: A combination of factors, including language barriers, oversimplification of images, and narrative simplicity

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the fifth basic taste that is now widely accepted?
Why can misconceptions be difficult to change?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are based on false information

options.label: C
options.text: Because they complement our desire for clear stories about the world

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not widely understood

multiple-choice.question: What should you do when encountering new information?

options.label: B
options.text: Ignore it if it contradicts what you already know

options.label: D
options.text: Only consider information from trusted sources

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's main message in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The tongue map is an accurate representation of how we experience taste

options.label: B
options.text: Misconceptions can be difficult to change, but it's essential to be open to new information

options.label: C
options.text: David Hänig's research was flawed and led to the development of the tongue map

options.label: D
options.text: The tongue map is a perfect example of how science can be messy and complicated

title: The rise of modern populism - Takis S. Pappas

multiple-choice.question: What was the state of Greece's politics in the mid-1970s?

options.label: A
options.text: Greece was experiencing a period of turmoil and instability.

options.label: B
options.text: Greece was on the path to stability with a new constitution and European institution negotiations.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main promise of Andreas Papandreou, the leader of PASOK, when he came to power in 1981?

options.label: A
options.text: To prioritize Greece's membership in NATO and the European Economic Community.

options.label: B
options.text: To govern for the betterment of the wealthy and powerful.

options.label: C
options.text: To govern for the betterment of the "common people" above all else.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the style of politics that emphasizes the will of the people over institutions?
What is the root of the term "populism"?
What type of democracy did many Western nations adopt in the aftermath of World War Two?
What are the three essential components of liberal democracy?

options.label: A
options.text: Acceptance of conflict, seeking common ground, and protection of minority rights

options.label: B
options.text: Prioritization of individual rights, protection of minority rights, and rule of law

options.label: C
options.text: Emphasis on the will of the people, disparagement of institutions, and protection of individual rights

options.label: D
options.text: Promotion of tolerance, protection of minority rights, and prioritization of social rights

multiple-choice.question: What is a common issue that liberal democracies have struggled with?
How do modern populists identify themselves?

options.label: A
options.text: As representatives of the wealthy and powerful

options.label: B
options.text: As embodying the "will of the people"

options.label: C
options.text: As protectors of individual and social rights

options.label: D
options.text: As promoters of tolerance and institutions

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of modern populist leaders?

options.label: A
options.text: They are often charismatic individuals who seek compromise and consensus

options.label: B
options.text: They are often charismatic individuals who identify themselves as embodying the "will of the people"

options.label: C
options.text: They are often authoritarian leaders who prioritize individual rights

options.label: D
options.text: They are often socialist leaders who prioritize social rights

multiple-choice.question: What can be a profound consequence of modern populist leaders' impact on politics?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased stability and trust in institutions

options.label: C
options.text: Destabilization of liberal democracy and erosion of public trust

options.label: D
options.text: Promotion of tolerance and protection of minority rights
